title: CCP propaganda quotes internet comment in criticizing U.S.-Taiwan arms sale: TW people ‚Äúwant vaccines, not weapons‚Äù

What‚Äôs Up Last Week?

Medigen vaccine clinical trial compensation: 10,000 U.S. Dollar in Paraguay, 6,000 N.T. Dollars in Taiwan

The Olympics and the pandemic are the most talked about topics of last week. Among pandemic-related issues, ‚ÄúIndoor dining in Taipei Metropolitan Area‚Äù, ‚ÄúCOVID-19 outbreaks in China‚Äù, ‚Äù5x stimulus vouchers‚Äù, ‚Äúvaccines inspection and sealing‚Äù, ‚Äúteahouses‚Äô reopening in Taipei‚Äù are the most popular. Aside from the games, ‚ÄúSmall S for Taiwan independence‚Äù and ‚ÄúMirage fighter jets accompanying Taiwan‚Äôs Olympians‚Äù are the 2 most popular issues related to the Olympics.

Under Taiwan‚Äôs current vaccine shortage, a new narrative from Chinese state media was observed, linking vaccines to arm sales to potentially sabotage Taiwan-U.S. relations. August 4th, U.S. State Department approved the first arms sale to Taiwan of the Biden Administration. Chinese state media Xinhua published a report titled ‚ÄúTaiwanese society criticizes U.S.-Taiwan arms sale: we want vaccines, not weapons.‚Äù Content of the report quoted ‚Äúanalysis‚Äù from Taiwan‚Äôs China Times, saying that the sale is ‚Äúrushed and overwhelming‚Äù (ÂèàÊÄ•ÂèàÁåõ) and financially problematic, while adapting a comment from a ‚ÄúTaiwanese netizen‚Äù: ‚ÄúTaiwan wants vaccines, not weapons.‚Äù

IORG has discovered multiple instances of Chinese state media quoting Taiwanese news reports and netizen comments in their propaganda responding to this U.S.-Taiwan arms sale. According to IORG‚Äôs database, at least 17 Chinese state media reports have quoted ‚ÄúTaiwanese netizens‚Äù, including 2 from Huanqiu, 1 from Xinhua, CCTV, and CRI, and 12 reposting identical content. These reports highlights individual comments in criticizing Taiwan and U.S. government of ‚Äúemptying out Taiwan‚Äù (Ê∑òÁ©∫Âè∞ÁÅ£), ‚Äúcheating Taiwan people‚Äôs money‚Äù (ÂèàÂÜçÈ®ôÂè∞ÁÅ£‰∫∫ÁöÑÈå¢), ‚Äúfraud‚Äù (Êï≤Ë©ê), characterizing U.S. arms as ‚Äúold‚Äù (‰∏≠Âè§), ‚Äúgarbage‚Äù (ÂûÉÂúæ), and ‚Äúscrap metal‚Äù (Âª¢Èêµ), and Taiwan‚Äôs payment ‚Äúprotection racket‚Äù (‰øùË≠∑Ë≤ª), claiming that ‚ÄúTaiwanese society‚Äù ‚Äúwant vaccines, not weapons‚Äù. Despite the lack of proper citation in these Chinese state media reports, IORG has identified that these comments are from the discussion sections of 3 Taiwanese news reports, published by United Daily News, China Times, and Yahoo News.

Taiwan‚Äôs locally-produced vaccine Medigen was found in an instance of false equivalency, a type of inference manipulation. August 3rd, Yi Media published a report titled ‚ÄúMedigen trial 10,000 U.S. dollars per person in Paraguay, 6,000 N.T. dollars in Taiwan.‚Äù The previous figure refers to the total cost of a single-person trial, while the latter refers to the ‚Äúnutrition subsidy‚Äù Medigen pays to each individual participating in its trials in Taiwan. Yi Media‚Äôs report presented two figures together, prompting readers to compare them, which cannot be compared, creating a false equivalency. After publication, former NTHU infectious disease physician Kong Hsiang-chi (Â≠îÁ••Áê™, or Lin Shi-bi ÊûóÊ∞èÂ£Å) criticized the report as ‚Äúfull of malice‚Äù and ‚Äúseverely misleading‚Äù. According to IORG‚Äôs database, 5 Facebook pages have spread this false equivalency and false information of ‚ÄúParaguayan paid 10,000 U.S. dollars each‚Äù: Big News Big Explosion (Â§ßÊñ∞ËÅûÂ§ßÁàÜÂç¶), Wan Direction Public Relations (Êó∫‰∏ñ‰ª£ÂåÖÊâìËÅΩ), Lo Chih-chiang (ÁæÖÊô∫Âº∑), Ko God Is Never Wrong; President Tsai Is Family (ÂçÉÈåØËê¨ÈåØÔºåÊüØÁ•û‰∏çÊúÉÊúâÈåØÔºÅÁàπË¶™Â®òË¶™Ôºå‰∏çÂ¶ÇÂ∞èËã±‰∏ªÂ∏≠Ë¶™ÔºÅ), and Li Mei-jhen (ÊùéÁúâËìÅ).

To close, suspicious or false information on ‚Äúdon‚Äôt get vaccinated‚Äù continues to appear. To reduce risks of infection and severe symptoms, IORG would like to encourage our readers to receive government-approved vaccines after medical consultation. Also, please stay alert for possible suspicious information on the ‚Äú5x stimulus vouchers‚Äù and the lambda variant. Verify before sharing. Be mindful of information manipulation.

Full version of this Dokidoki Alert Weekly is available in Taiwanese Mandarin. Please visit https://iorg.tw/da/10 for more‚Ä¶
